episodes.title: Damon Wayans Defends Dangerous Jehovah’s Witness Beliefs — But the Bible Doesn’t
episodes.description:
Damon Wayans recently went on Club Shay Shay with Shannon Sharpe and publicly defended several core Jehovah’s Witness beliefs. Some of those beliefs aren’t just unbiblical... they’re dangerous.

In this video, I respond directly to Damon Wayans’ claims about Jehovah’s Witness doctrine — including teachings on paganism, holidays, and blood transfusions that have real-world consequences and cost lives.

Whether you’re a current Jehovah’s Witness, PIMO, ex-JW, or someone encountering Watchtower doctrine for the first time, this video walks through the claims step by step and follows them all the way to their conclusions.

🔔 Subscribe to @exilesandpilgrims for clear, thoughtful analysis of Jehovah’s Witness beliefs vs historical Christianity.

▶️ Watch next: Jehovah’s Witnesses Claim Christianity Apostatized — But Did It?
👉 https://youtu.be/r4dt2O52iDo

🔍 Topics covered:
Damon Wayans, Jehovah’s Witnesses, Watchtower, the Governing Body, blood transfusions, JW blood doctrine, biblical authority, Christian history, JW beliefs, ex-Jehovah’s Witness, PIMO, high-control religion, cult dynamics, and Scripture.

episodes.title: Jehovah’s Witnesses Claim Christianity Apostatized — But Did It?
episodes.description:
Jehovah’s Witnesses claim that Christianity fell into a "Great Apostasy" almost immediately after the apostles died.

According to the Watchtower, the early Church collapsed in the second century, true doctrine was lost, and Christianity remained corrupt until the organization was “restored” centuries later by Charles Russell, Joseph Rutherford, and the Governing Body.

But did that actually happen?

And more importantly — does history support the Governing Body’s claim of a “Great Apostasy”?

In this video, I examine the core Jehovah’s Witness teaching about early Christianity apostatizing, including how figures like David Splane of the Governing Body frame Church history, Constantine, and post-apostolic Christianity.

This isn’t about Catholic vs Protestant debates or defending any one tradition. It’s about whether the historical record matches the Watchtower’s narrative.

In this episode, we look closely at:

→ What Jehovah’s Witnesses mean by the “Great Apostasy”
→ How the Governing Body claims early Christianity became corrupted
→ Whether early Christian writings actually support that claim
→ The role Constantine is often blamed for — and what really changed
→ Why the apostasy narrative is essential to Watchtower authority

When an organization claims exclusive truth by asserting that all other Christians were wrong for 1,800 years, the burden of proof matters.

And when questioning that narrative is discouraged, it raises a deeper question: Is the Great Apostasy a historical conclusion — or a theological necessity?

Whether you’re a current Jehovah’s Witness, PIMO, ex-JW, or simply researching early Christianity and Watchtower doctrine, this video will help you examine a claim that almost everything else depends on.

🔔 Subscribe to @exilesandpilgrims for thoughtful, historical analysis of Jehovah’s Witness beliefs, Watchtower history, and high-control groups — without fear-mongering or hype.

▶️ Watch next: Joe Rogan Called Jehovah’s Witnesses a Cult — Here’s Why That Matters
👉 https://youtu.be/4VBSj6zd1Fw

🔍 Topics covered
Great Apostasy, Jehovah’s Witnesses, Watchtower, Governing Body, David Splane, early Christianity, Church history, Constantine, Ignatius, Irenaeus, JW doctrine, apostasy, Watchtower teachings, Christian history, ex-Jehovah’s Witness, PIMO, high-control religion, and Watchtower theology

episodes.title: Joe Rogan Called Jehovah’s Witnesses a Cult — Here’s Why That Matters
episodes.description:
Joe Rogan called out what many Jehovah’s Witnesses are afraid to confront — the question of whether the religion operates like a cult.

And he didn’t say it once… he said it twice.

The second time, Joe Rogan sat down with former Jehovah’s Witness Kurt Metzger, who described what it was like growing up inside the organization and leaving it behind.

This isn’t about sparking outrage or clickbait. It’s why the word “cult” hits such a nerve for Jehovah’s Witnesses, and why hearing it from voices like Joe Rogan matters now more than ever.

In this video, I break down what Joe Rogan actually said, why Jehovah’s Witnesses are conditioned to distrust outside criticism, and how the Watchtower’s authority depends on discouraging honest examination.

When an organization claims divine guidance but punishes questioning, isolates dissenters, and frames outside voices as dangerous, you have to ask: Is the real problem criticism — or control?

Watch the full video to learn...
→ Why Joe Rogan’s comments resonate so strongly with current and former JWs
→ How the Watchtower conditions members to avoid outside perspectives
→ Why the word “cult” triggers fear instead of discussion
→ And what each of us can do to help more JWs wake up

Whether you’re a current Jehovah’s Witness, PIMO, ex-JW, or simply researching Watchtower beliefs, this video will help connect dots that are rarely examined openly in the JW community.

🔔 Subscribe to @exilesandpilgrims for clear, thoughtful analysis of Jehovah’s Witness doctrine, Watchtower history, and high-control religion — without fear-mongering or hype.

▶️ Watch next: The Founder of Jehovah’s Witnesses Believed WHAT?! (Charles Taze Russell Exposed)
👉 https://youtu.be/9mjjWX4OFh4

🔍 Topics covered
Joe Rogan, Jehovah’s Witnesses, Watchtower, Governing Body, JW beliefs, cult psychology, Kurt Metzger, high-control religion, Jehovah’s Witness doctrine, JW policy changes, shunning, disfellowshipping, ex-Jehovah’s Witness, PIMO, and Watchtower history

episodes.title: The Founder of Jehovah’s Witnesses Believed WHAT?! (Charles Taze Russell Exposed)
episodes.description:
Charles Taze Russell didn’t just found what would become Jehovah’s Witnesses... he held beliefs that most modern JWs have NEVER been told about.

One of the most surprising? Russell believed the Great Pyramid of Giza in Egypt was built under God's direction — as a prophetic “stone witness” meant to confirm Bible chronology and divine truth.

In this video, I walk through Charles Taze Russell’s pyramid theology, where it came from, how seriously it was treated in early Watchtower teachings, and why it was eventually abandoned.

This isn’t speculation or rumor. It’s documented Watchtower history.

We’ll look at:

→ What Charles Taze Russell actually believed about the Great Pyramid
→ How pyramid measurements were used to predict biblical timelines
→ Why early Watchtower publications promoted pyramid prophecy
→ When and why the organization quietly distanced itself from these ideas
→ And what this reveals about claims of divine guidance and “new light”

If God chose Charles Taze Russell as his mouthpiece, as he claimed, then it's fair to ask: What did this man believe? Because whether Jehovah's Witnesses like it or not, he sits at the foundation of their belief system. 

Whether you’re a current Jehovah’s Witness, PIMO, ex-JW, or simply interested in Watchtower history, this video sheds light on a chapter that’s rarely discussed — but deeply revealing.

🔔 Subscribe to @exilesandpilgrims for thoughtful, honest analysis of Jehovah’s Witness beliefs, Watchtower history, and religious authority.

▶️ Watch next: Jehovah’s Witnesses Are Unrecognizable (Here’s What Will Change Next)
👉 https://youtu.be/Ha0Q8C_GGek

🔍 Topics covered:
Charles Taze Russell, Jehovah’s Witnesses, Watchtower history, Great Pyramid of Giza, pyramid prophecy, Russell pyramid beliefs, early Watchtower teachings, Jehovah’s Witness doctrine, JW history, Governing Body, new light, Watchtower theology, ex Jehovah’s Witness, PIMO, Bible chronology, religious authority

episodes.title: Jehovah’s Witnesses Are Unrecognizable (Here’s What Will Change Next)
episodes.description:
Jehovah’s Witnesses are changing — fast. Rules that were once treated as matters of loyalty are suddenly being rewritten, softened, or quietly abandoned. And if you’ve been paying attention, the pattern is impossible to ignore.

In this video, I break down the most likely Jehovah’s Witness beliefs and policies to change next, based on what’s already changed — including beards, dress standards, toasting, reporting hours, and higher education.

This isn’t wild speculation. It’s about recognizing a clear trajectory.

We’ll look at:

→ Why Jehovah’s Witnesses look nothing like they did just a decade ago
→ How hard rules are rapidly being replaced by "conscience matters”
→ Which teachings are under the most pressure right now
→ And why beliefs like birthdays, shunning, and certain holidays may be next

Since the Governing Body claims divine guidance, you have to ask: Does the truth really need constant revisions?

Whether you’re a current Jehovah’s Witness, PIMO, ex-JW, or just curious about Watchtower doctrine, this video will help connect the dots.

episodes.title: Jehovah Is NOT God’s Name (And Even the Watchtower Admits It)
episodes.description:
Jehovah’s Witnesses are taught that using the name “Jehovah” is essential for true worship. But here’s the problem...

“Jehovah” is not the original name of God, and even the Watchtower organization admits it.

In this video, I walk through:

→ Where the name Jehovah actually came from
→ Why Hebrew scholars overwhelmingly favor Yahweh instead
→ What the Watchtower itself says in Insight on the Scriptures
→ Why the divine name does not appear in any ancient New Testament manuscripts
→ And why there is no record of Jesus ever using the divine name

Jehovah’s Witnesses are told that God’s name was removed from the Bible, but the Watchtower also claims the Scriptures were preserved with “minute attention to detail.” Both claims cannot be true.

This video isn’t about attacking people. It’s about examining history, manuscripts, and the Watchtower’s own admissions — calmly, clearly, and honestly.

If you’re a Jehovah’s Witness, a former JW, or someone questioning Watchtower teachings, this is a conversation worth having.

🔔 Subscribe @exilesandpilgrims  for more videos exposing contradictions in Watchtower doctrine using Scripture, history, and the organization’s own publications.

▶️ Watch next: 10 Questions Jehovah’s Witnesses Must Answer (But Can’t)
👉 https://youtu.be/Gvm5AN_1WEY

Here's a link to the June 2015 broadcast referenced in the video: https://www.jw.org/en/library/videos/#en/mediaitems/StudioMonthlyPrograms/pub-jwb_201506_1_VIDEO

episodes.title: 10 Questions Jehovah’s Witnesses Must Answer (But Can’t)
episodes.description:
Jehovah’s Witnesses are taught they have “the truth,” but these 10 questions expose serious contradictions in core Watchtower teachings.

In this video, I walk through 10 powerful questions every Jehovah’s Witness must answer (but can’t). These aren’t “gotcha” questions or emotional arguments. They’re simple, biblical, and logical questions that challenge foundational JW beliefs.

01:03 – Why obey the Governing Body if they admit they are often wrong?
01:56 – What belief are you certain will never change?
02:17 – If Thomas called Jesus "my Lord and my God," why don't you? 
02:44 – If only God is good... then is Jesus good?
03:03 – If Jesus isn't your mediator, then who is?
04:00 – Why did Jesus choose JWs in 1919 while they taught false doctrines?
04:44 – If Jesus never used the name Jehovah, why is it required today?
05:12 – If God's name was removed from Scripture, can we trust the Bible?
05:40 – If shunning is loving, why didn't Jesus practice it?
06:03 – Could anything convince you that JWs aren't the true religion?

If you found this video helpful, you may also want to watch: 
👉 The LIE the Entire Jehovah’s Witness Religion Is Built On (1919 Exposed) | https://youtu.be/Vyt5JrhJpts

If you want more videos like this, subscribe @exilesandpilgrims for future discussions on Jehovah’s Witness theology and biblical, historical Christianity.

episodes.title: This Jehovah’s Witness Called Me Judas Iscariot… So I Responded
episodes.description:
A Jehovah’s Witness publicly called me a liar, a slanderer, and even “Judas Iscariot.”

Instead of firing back with insults, I'm responding calmly, directly, and with reason.

In this video, I address the accusations head-on and explain why disagreement doesn’t require character assassination, why labeling sincere Christians as “Judas” is spiritually reckless, and how this kind of rhetoric exposes deeper problems within Jehovah’s Witness theology and culture.

This response examines:

→ Why dissent inside the Watchtower is treated as betrayal

→ How labels like “Judas” and “apostate” shut down conscience and discussion

→ Why truth claims that can’t be questioned rely on intimidation instead

If you’re a Jehovah’s Witness, former JW, or someone exploring Christianity outside the Watchtower, this video will help you recognize these tactics and respond to them clearly.

Because this isn’t about attacking people or winning arguments.
It’s about truth, conscience, and following Christ — even when they call you every name in the book.

episodes.title: Why Jehovah’s Witnesses Don't Celebrate Christmas (But SHOULD!)
episodes.description:
Jehovah’s Witnesses reject Christmas because they believe it’s pagan, unbiblical, and dishonoring to God. But when you actually look at history, Scripture, and the early Christian writings, the Watchtower’s arguments fall apart — fast.

In this video, we take a clear, honest look at the real evidence:

• What early Christians actually believed about the birth of Jesus
• Why December 25 wasn’t borrowed from pagan Rome
• What Hippolytus wrote about the Nativity in the early 200s
• The truth about Sol Invictus — and why the dates don’t line up
• Why the “pagan origins” argument collapses logically and biblically
• Why the New Testament doesn’t forbid celebrating Christ’s birth
• How the Watchtower oversimplifies history to justify its stance

It's true — the early Bible Students (and even Bethel) celebrated Christmas… but that’s not the biggest issue. The real problem is that the organization’s reasoning today isn’t historically accurate, and it doesn’t reflect how Christians — including the earliest ones — understood the Incarnation.

If you’re a Jehovah’s Witness, someone studying with JWs, or someone who left the organization and wants clarity, you’ll see the biblical and historical case laid out plainly.

Christmas isn’t about paganism. It’s about Christ coming into the world — and that’s worth celebrating.

Subscribe for more:
👉  @exilesandpilgrims  

Watch next:
👉 The LIE the Entire Jehovah’s Witness Religion Is Built On (1919 Exposed): https://youtu.be/Vyt5JrhJpts

Thanks for watching, and Merry Christmas. 🎄✨

episodes.title: If Your “Truth” Can’t Be Questioned… It Isn’t Truth (From a Former Jehovah’s Witness)
episodes.description:
If your “truth” can’t be questioned… it isn’t truth at all. Real truth doesn’t fear examination — only fragile belief systems do. 

In this video, I explain why genuine faith welcomes honest questions, and why spiritual authority should never depend on shutting down critical thinking.

As a former Jehovah’s Witness, I know what it’s like to be told that questioning “The Truth” is dangerous. But Jesus never taught a faith built on fear or insulation. Real Christianity invites examination because truth actually stands up to it.

Whether you’re a current or former JW, a Christian wrestling with doubts, or someone asking what truth really is, hopefully this video will help you make sense of the difference between truth, ideology, and control.

episodes.title: The LIE the Entire Jehovah’s Witness Religion Is Built On (1919 Exposed)
episodes.description:
Most Jehovah’s Witnesses don't know the full story about 1919 — or why the entire Jehovah’s Witness organization, the Governing Body’s authority, and the faithful and discreet slave doctrine depend on it.

In this video, I break down the Watch Tower claim that Jesus conducted a spiritual inspection from 1914–1919, chose the Watch Tower Society as his “faithful and discreet slave,” and granted the Governing Body exclusive authority over all spiritual truth.

The problem? None of it lines up with Scripture, history, or even the organization’s own teachings.

I walk through the timeline, the circular logic, the failed prophecies leading up to 1919, and why this doctrine is the weak point of the entire Jehovah’s Witness belief system. 

Whether you’re a current JW, an ex-JW, or someone researching the religion, this is the doctrine you have to understand.

The teaching that Jesus “inspected all churches” from 1914–1919 and chose the Watch Tower Society as God’s only channel isn’t found anywhere in Scripture — not one verse.

If this doctrine collapses, everything else collapses with it.

episodes.title: Jehovah’s Witnesses Used to Worship Jesus... Now They Call It Idolatry
episodes.description:
Jehovah’s Witnesses will tell you that worshipping Jesus is idolatry.
But what most JWs don’t realize is that their own publications once commanded it.

For decades, the Watchtower taught that Jehovah required everyone to worship Christ Jesus. Then, without apology, they reversed course and called that same act “false worship.”

In this episode, I show the original Watchtower sources, explain when and why the change happened, and explore what it means for anyone who still believes the organization speaks for God.

If “the truth” can change on something as fundamental as who deserves worship... what does that say about the source?

Watch till the end — this one’s eye-opening.

You may also want to...

•  Watch "The Truth About Jehovah’s Witness Baptism in 5 Minutes (Most JWs Don’t Know This)" → https://youtu.be/wI5BaF81QAQ
• Subscribe for new episodes every week → https://www.youtube.com/@exilesandpilgrims

#JehovahsWitnesses #ExJW #JW #JehovahsWitness #christianity 

Watchtower sources referenced:
•  2023 Annual Meeting 
•  w93 1/15 pp. 20-25
•  w63 1/15 pp. 53-56
•  Page 339 of the 1939 Watchtower
•  Page 32 of the 1945 Yearbook
•  Awake!  |  April 8, 2000
•  w57 6/15 pp. 369-375
